awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Neotoma Paleoecology Database, Community-led Cyberinfrastructure for Global Change Research
awd_abstract_narration:
This Division of Earth Sciences Geoinformatics collaborative award supports continued development of Neotoma, a web-accessible centralized data clearinghouse for paleoecological data for which initial development support was provided by the EAR Geoinformatics Program (EAR- 0948652).  This effort will enhance the current Neotoma platform by: 1) maximizing rates of data ingest through on-going data mobilization campaigns, recruitment and training of new data stewards, and development of facilitation software; 2) expanding the Neotoma data model to facilitate new proxy acquisition and secondary data including organic biomarkers, isotopic data from faunal specimens, and faunal taphonomic information; 3) developing new tools for data visualization and scientific exploration; 4) fostering engagement and growth of the Neotoma research community through support for a series of workshops intended to train data users, data stewards, and teachers, and by development of an on-line blog.

The Neotoma geoinformatics platform will promote integrative studies of the biotic impacts of climate change over the past five million years by allowing greater access to previously collected geoscience data sets of relevance and the tools to support analysis at marginal cost.  The project will promote community engagement, support ease of data set ingestion, address PI team succession and promote educational module development.  This award directly addresses OMB Memo M-13-13 ?Open Data Policy-Managing Information as an Asset.?

por.por_cntn:
The Neotoma Paleoecology Database supports global-change research by providing an open, sustainable, community-curated repository for multiple kinds of fossil data. Neotoma achieves high data quality by working closely with expert contributors and stewards. Neotoma specializes in records spanning the last few centuries to million years. By consolidating many kinds of data into one centralized resource, Neotoma lowers costs and enhances sustainability while offering paleoecologists a high-quality data resource. Neotoma includes data on many characteristics measured in paleoecological studies:  pollen, diatoms, ostracods, insects, testate amoebae, vertebrates, geochemistry, chronology, water chemistry and others.   

Work done under this subaward focused on entering diatom data into Neotoma, which currently contains over 3,000 diatom datasets from North and South America. Diatom distributions are strongly influenced by environmental conditions such as pH, conductivity, nutrients and light conditions.  Diatoms are therefore excellent ecological indicators and are widely used in paleoecological studies.  During the course of the grant, several hundred diatom datasets were added to Neotoma.  These represent both stratigraphic data for cores and surface samples.  The surface sample data, along with corresponding water chemistry data, can be used by the scientific community as part of calibration datasets to develop new inference models to infer environmental conditions.   These models, as well as existing ones, can be used to reconstruct ecological conditions and address issues such as climate change, eutrophication and acid rain.  A big advantage of having a large database with a continent-wide distribution of paleo datasets is the ability to study large-scale regional ecological trends.  Neotoma provides a valuable service by making it much easier for scientists to access multiple datasets than if they had to find and assemble all the datasets themselves.

Four Drexel co-op students worked six months each to add diatom data and develop new protocols for working with diatom data.  They learned new software, gained experience with databases and learned about diatoms, lake ecosystems and issues such as climate change and eutrophication. Teaching modules were developed for high school students to help them understand the importance and use of diatoms in quantifying ecological change.   Data were transferred from the Diatom Paleoecological Data Cooperative (DPDC), funded previously by NSF, to Neotoma where they will be more widely available. Data entered into Neotoma were provided by many diatom ecologists.  Considerable time was spent working with them to prepare their data and discussing how their data could be used in future studies. A key benefit of adding the diatom data to Neotoma is that they will remain available to the public; some may otherwise be lost because they were never put in a public archive. Diatom data in Neotoma and their potential uses were described at scientific meetings.
